ClusteringHelper¶

ClusteringHelper.order_clusters(data_df, clustered_data_df)¶
Parameters

  • data_df – A DataFrame representation of all of the raw data we are reading

  • clustered_data_df – A DataFrame representation of all of the clustered data we are reading

Returns

A new DataFrame which stores the new clustered values along with the original data

Orders the clusters so they correlate with their original hardness values

ClusteringHelper.perform_agglomerative(data_df, num_clusters=3, linkage='ward')¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • num_clusters – The number of clusters we are clustering the data into

  • linkage – Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion.

Returns

Clustered data

Performs agglomerative clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_birch(data_df, num_clusters=3)¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • num_clusters – The number of clusters we are clustering the data into

Returns

Clustered data

Performs birch clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_clustering(data_df, clustering_details={'num_clusters': '3', 'random_state': '0'}, clustering_method='K Means', additional_outlier_clusters=False)¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data we are clustering

  • clustering_details – The details involving the method of clustering we are doing

  • clustering_method – The clustering method we are using

  • additional_outlier_clusters – Whether or not to make any outliers separate clusters, with one cluster on either side of the set of clusters

Returns

The clustered data based on the data_df column

Performs clustering on the data inside the data_df based off of the clustering method and details. It calls the necessary clustering method helper to perform it’s clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_dbscan(data_df, eps=0.75, min_samples=100, algorithm='auto')¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • eps – The maximum distance between two samples for one to be considered as in the neighborhood of the other. This is not a maximum bound on the distances of points within a cluster. This is the most important DBSCAN parameter to choose appropriately for your data set and distance function.

  • min_samples – The number of samples (or total weight) in a neighborhood for a point to be considered as a core point. This includes the point itself.

  • algorithm – The algorithm to be used by the NearestNeighbors module to compute pointwise distances and find nearest neighbors. See NearestNeighbors module documentation for details.

Returns

Clustered data

Performs DBSCAN clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_decon(data_df, m_val=3, max_iter=1500, limit=1e-06, label='Hardness', show_plots=False, save_plots=False, save_dir='', cluster_iter=0, cluster_name='')¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • m_val – The number of clusters we are clustering the data into

  • max_iter – The max number of iterations to run the deconvolution method with, should be an integer, 1500 by default

  • limit – The limit or degree of precision we are using, it is a value used in the decon method to check if a solution is valid or not

  • label – The column we are using for analysis, can be ‘Hardness’ for example

  • show_plots – A boolean of whether or not to show the plots

  • save_plots – A boolean of whether or not to save the plots

  • save_dir – The directory to save the plots in

  • cluster_iter – The iteration of this cluster configuration

  • cluster_name – The name of this cluster configuration

Returns

Clustered data

Performs Deconvolution clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_hdbscan(data_df, metric='euclidean', min_cluster_size=10, min_samples=200)¶
Parameters

  • min_samples –

  • min_cluster_size –

  • metric –

  • data_df – The data being clustered

Returns

Clustered data

Performs HDBSCAN clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_k_means(data_df, num_clusters=3, random_state=0)¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • num_clusters – The number of clusters we are clustering the data into

  • random_state – The random seed the environment is set to before clustering. The method uses randomness so this allows for reproducibility

Returns

Clustered data

Performs K Means clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_k_medoids(data_df, num_clusters=3, init='random', random_state=0)¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • num_clusters – The number of clusters we are clustering the data into

  • init – Specify medoid initialization method. ‘random’ selects n_clusters elements from the dataset. ‘heuristic’ picks the n_clusters points with the smallest sum distance to every other point. ‘k-medoids++’ follows an approach based on k-means++_, and in general, gives initial medoids which are more separated than those generated by the other methods. ‘build’ is a greedy initialization of the medoids used in the original PAM algorithm. Often ‘build’ is more efficient but slower than other initializations on big datasets and it is also very non-robust, if there are outliers in the dataset, use another initialization.

  • random_state – The random seed the environment is set to before clustering. The method uses randomness so this allows for reproducibility

Returns

Clustered data

Performs K Medoids clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_optics(data_df, eps=inf, min_samples=100, algorithm='auto')¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • eps – The maximum distance between two samples for one to be considered as in the neighborhood of the other. By default it assumes the same value as max_eps. Used only when cluster_method=’dbscan’.

  • min_samples – The number of samples in a neighborhood for a point to be considered as a core point. Also, up and down steep regions can’t have more than min_samples consecutive non-steep points. Expressed as an absolute number or a fraction of the number of samples (rounded to be at least 2).

  • algorithm – Algorithm used to compute the nearest neighbors

Returns

Clustered data

Performs OPTICS clustering

ClusteringHelper.perform_spectral(data_df, num_clusters=3, assign_labels='discretize', affinity='rbf', random_state=0)¶
Parameters

  • data_df – The data being clustered

  • num_clusters – The number of clusters we are clustering the data into

  • assign_labels – The strategy to use to assign labels in the embedding space. There are two ways to assign labels after the laplacian embedding. k-means can be applied and is a popular choice. But it can also be sensitive to initialization. Discretization is another approach which is less sensitive to random initialization.

  • affinity – How to construct the affinity matrix.

  • random_state – The random seed the environment is set to before clustering. The method uses randomness so this allows for reproducibility

Returns

Clustered data

Performs Spectral clustering

ClusteringHelper.transform_to_df(data_list)¶
Parameters

data_list – A list representation of the data

Returns

A DataFrame made up of the list taken into the method

Transforms the list into a DataFrame with the appropriate column name
